### Barem Tema 2
Requirement: Consider an application OrderManagement for processing customer orders. The application uses (minimally) the following classes: Order, OPDept (Order Processing Department), Customer, Product, and Warehouse. The classes OPDept and Warehouse use a BinarySearchTree for storing orders.
    + Analyze the application domain, determine the structure and behavior of its classes, identify use cases.
    + Generate use case diagrams, an extended UML class diagram, two sequence diagrams and an activity diagram.
    + Implement and test the application classes. Use javadoc for documenting the classes.
    + Design, write and test a Java program for order management using the classes designed at question c). The program should include a set of utility operations such as under-stock, over-stock, totals, filters, etc.

    * respectarea claselor minimale din enuntul problemei si folosirea BST - 1p
    * admin view si regular user view - 1p
    * operatii admin (ex: adaugare/stergere de produse - 1p, modificarea stocului - 1p)
    * operatii user normal (filtrare produse - 1p, plasare comenzi - 1p, pastrare si vizualizare istoric comenzi - 1p)
    * documentatie - 3p

### Git Help - pushing to a remote repository
Din cate am observat, unii dintre voi aveti probleme cu Git-ul asa ca va sugerez sa cititi [urmatoarea sectiune](https://help.github.com/articles/adding-a-file-to-a-repository-from-the-command-line/) si sa incercati apoi sa faceti push din nou (folosind Git Bash). 

### Reguli Laborator PT

* prezenta
    * participarea la toate laboratoarele este obligatorie 
    * se accepta maxim 3 absente in situatii exceptionale (daca sunt anuntata inainte)

* teme
    * 5 teme cu predare din 2 in 2 saptamani
    * fiecare saptamana de delay => -1p la nota finala a temei respective
    * intr-un laborator se poate preda o singura tema restanta
    * in saptamana premergatoare sesiunii se poate preda o singura tema restanta
    * exista posibilitatea obtinerii unor bonusuri anuntate pe parcursul semestrului

* predarea temelor
    * codul sursa
    * javadoc pe clasa si pe metodele cu logica de business
    * documentatie (3000 de cuvinte, accent pe diagrame: use case, class & sequence) avand structura
        * Obiectivul temei
        * Analiza problemei, modelare, scenarii, cazuri de utilizare
        * Proiectare (diagrame UML, structuri de date, proiectare clase, interfete, relatii, packages, algoritmi, interfata utilizator)
        * Implementare si testare
        * Rezultate
        * Concluzii, ce s-a invatat din tema, dezvoltari ulterioare
        * Bibliografie
    * la predare, veti primi o intrebare intrebare legata de tema (fie pe baza codului, fie pe baza documentatiei)

* `    if (labFinalGrade >= 5 && attendances >= 11) {
           return "pass"; 
       } else {
           return "fail";
       }`


### Barem Tema 1
Requirement: Propose, design and implement a system for polynomial processing. Consider the polynomials of one variable and integer coefficients.

   * documentatie - 2p
   * interfata grafica - 1p
   * adunare - 1p
   * scadere - 1p
   * inmultire - 1.5p
   * impartire - 1.5p
   * integrare si derivare / graficul functiei / calculul radacinilor- 2p

### Clean code conventions
"Always code as if the guy who ends up maintaining your code will be a violent psychopath who knows where you live. Code for readability."

   Clean code can be achieved by 
   * meaningful names (please see ch. 9 of the recommended reading material)
      * pronounceable, searchable, avoid encodings
      * intention-revealing names
   * language fundamentals (please see ch. 10.1 of the recommended reading material)
      * minimize the accessibility of classes and members (use encapsulation)
   * methods
      * small, easy to read & understand
      * do exactly one thing
      * keep number of arguments minimal & justified 
   * objects & data (Law of Demeter <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_Demeter>)
     * keep the variables private when you don't want anyone to depend on them
     * hide implementation, expose interface
     * "talk to friends, not strangers":
        * a method `f` of class `C` should only call methods of:
            * `C`
            * objects created by `f`
            * objects passed as an argument of `f`
            * objects held in an instance of `C`
        * a method should NOT invoke methods on objects that are returned by any allowed functions
   * formatting (please see ch 4, 6 and 7 of the recommended reading material)
   * comments (please see ch. 5 of the recommended reading material)
       * explain your intend, but avoid noisy or redundant comments
   * exceptions & error handling
       * have a clear separation between error handling and business logic (define a normal flow and the exceptional flows)
       * avoid returning/passing `null` in case of exceptions (difficult to handle) - thrown an exception instead
       * provide context (informative messages) with exceptions

Clean code should obey the following principles:
   * single responsibility & high cohesion
       * specialized classes/methods
       * keep modules/elements together
   * low coupling
       * minimize dependencies

Recommended reading: <https://oracle.com/technetwork/java/codeconventions-150003.pdf>
